key_title: Key to the species of Olearia

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Asteraceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G., Lander, N.S.
source.title: Olearia
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria Vol. 4, Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G., Lander, N.S. (1999). Olearia. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria Vol. 4, Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves opposite
Leaves alternate (but sometimes in small clusters)
Margins toothed
Margins entire
Leaves thin-textured, viscid; involucres 2–3-seriate; near-coastal shrub near Lakes Entrance
Leaves rather stiff, not viscid; involucres 3–6-seriate; montane to alpine shrubs

Indumentum on lower leaf and peduncles of ascending Y-shaped hairs, making surfaces appear somewhat scruffy; leaves prominently reticulate-veined above (on dried specimens); involucre cup-shaped, innermost bracts usually more than 6 mm long

Indumentum on lower leaf and peduncles of appressed T-shaped hairs, appearing somewhat smooth or silky; upper leaf surface not or indistinctly reticulate-veined; involucre conical, innermost bracts less than 6 mm long
Ray florets 2–4; pappus bristles often pink; leaf length-width ratio usually less than 6
Ray florets 5–8; pappus bristles white to straw-coloured; leaf length-width ratio usually more than 6
Indumentum of simple (sometimes glandular) hairs and/or bristles, or surfaces apparently glabrous (then often viscid or resinous)
Indumentum (branchlets and leaf undersurfaces) of stellate or centrifixed (T-shaped or Y-shaped) hairs
Hairs stellate
Hairs T-shaped or Y-shaped
Capitula few, 35 mm diam. or more, on relatively long, thick peduncles; reticulate venation impressed on upper surfaces of leaves; leaf-margins entire to sinuate-toothed
Capitula often numerous, to 35 mm diam., on slender peduncles; reticulate venation prominent, pale, somewhat raised on upper surfaces of leaves; leaf-margins often sharply toothed
Tall shrub or tree to c. 10 m high; largest leaves 70–120 mm long or more, the lower surfaces silvery with a thin, closely appressed indumentum; capitula numerous in corymbose panicles
Shrubs to 2 m high; largest leaves to c. 80 mm long, lower surfaces white, rusty or pinkish, with thickish layer of appressed or spreading hairs; capitula relatively few, mostly in simple corymbs
Ray florets 2 or 3 per capitulum; leaves obovate to elliptic, to c. 30 mm long, obtuse, with evenly denticulate margins
Ray florets 4–7 per capitulum; leaves ovate to elliptic or narrowly obovate, mostly longer than 30 mm, acute, with (often irregularly) serrate or biserrate margins, often undulate
Indumentum of closely appressed T-shaped hairs
Indumentum of somewhat spreading to woolly Y-shaped hairs
Leaves entire, finally glabrous above (or remaining pubescent along the midrib), entirely covered beneath by white to buff woolly indumentum; Midlands and Otway Plain only
Leaves crenate to distantly serrate, pubescent and/or scabrous above, loosely covered beneath by brownish hairs; far East Gippsland only
Involucre more than 14 mm diam.; leaves elliptic to spathulate, entire or lobed in the distal half, upper surface grey-green and moderately to densely stellate-hairy
Involucre less than 14 mm diam., or if more than 14 mm diam. then leaves not as above
Capitula sessile; leaves c. spahtulate; very rare, in upper Tambo River catchment only
Capitula pedunculate; leaves elliptic, oblong or obovate; localised in Snowfields on and near Bogong High Plains
Involucral bracts subequal; capitula often solitary and terminal; lateral veins of leaves not apparent; wiry shrub usually of wet lowland heaths

Involucral bracts graduating (i.e. outer significantly shorter than inner); capitula usually in corymbs or panicles (but solitary and sessile in O. brevipedunculata); lateral veins of leaves apparent; rarely occurring in wet heathlands
Leaves tuberculate on the upper surface; lower surface with indumentum of coarse, golden or dark yellowish hairs
Upper leaf surface glabrous or variously hairy with stellate or apparently simple hairs, but lacking tubercles; lower surface with close, dense white, grey or pale yellowish hairs

Leaves deeply wrinkled due to strongly impressed veins; upper surface with large (more than 0.2 mm long) tubercules; leave shape very variable, from oblong to broadly elliptic; margins sinuate, coarsely toothed or lobed, rarely entire; scattered in eastern Victoria with an isolated population at Mt Buangor
Leaves not deeply wrinkled; upper surface with small (less than 0.2 mm long), often deciduous tubercles; leaves usually narrow-ovate and regualrly toothed; restricted to the Otways
Leaves greyish above; capitula solitary and sessile; restricted to upper subalpine and alpine areas
Leaves usually green above; capitula pedunculate, usually in panicles; widespread from near sea-level to alps

Leaves lanceolate to narrow-ovate, usually thin-textured with strongly impressed veins; not distinctly glandular, lacking a foetid odour when crushed; margins usually entire or sinuate, rarely serrate

Leaves narrow-ovate, ovate, oblong or obovate, rarely lanceolate, usually thick-textured with veins not or only slighlty impressed; distinctly glandular on one or both surfaces (glands often hidden by hairs) and producing a foetid odour when crushed; margins lobed or toothed, rarely entire
Branchlets (and usually leaf undersurfaces) whitish-cottony, sometimes also with simple bristles and/or glands
Branchlets and leaf undersurfaces lacking (or with only sparse) cottony hairs, either glabrous (but sometimes viscid or resinous) or with simple bristles (sometimes glandular)
Capitula sessile in leaf-axils; ligules of ray florets often not developed
Capitula terminal and/or pedunculate (sometimes appearing axillary when terminating very short lateral branchlets); ligules of ray florets conspicuous, distinctly exceeding the involucre
Leaves (8–) 10–25 mm long, the undersurface distinctly white-cottony; strictly coastal shrub
Leaves to 8 mm long, the undersurface almost or quite obscured by the revolute margins; mostly inland areas, rare along coasts
Leaves to 4.5 mm long, produced in dense clusters along branchlets; coastal
Leaves to 8 mm long, scattered to loosely clustered along branchlets; mostly inland, but approaching coast in Anglesea area
Ligules of ray florets well developed (3–5 per capitulum), 1.5–2.5 mm long
Ligules of ray florets not developed or vestigial, not exceeding styles of florets

Capitula terminal on very short lateral branches, or pedunculate from axils; leaves linear to narrow-elliptic (if ever ovate then less than 3 mm long and densely clustered), with undersurfaces largely concealed by revolute margins; involucral bracts pubescent or glabrous
Capitula terminal on normal branches; leaves obovate to elliptic (1.5–) 3–15 mm long, with undersurfaces apparent, not clustered along branches; at least the outer involucral bracts pubescent

Leaves 3–22 mm long, not produced in distinct clusters along branches; capitula usually pedunculate from upper axils; indumentum either including erect bristles, or almost entirely gummed down from resinous exudate

Leaves to 3 (rarely to 4.5) mm long, distinctly clustered along branches on very reduced lateral branches; capitula terminal (sessile or subsessile) on lateral branches; indumentum neither including bristles nor gummed down by a resinous exudate
Indumentum bristly, the cottony hairs (sparse to dense) not gummed down; widespread shrub, but not in mallee areas
Indumentum not including bristles, the cottony hairs almost entirely gummed down by a resinous exudate (but usually remaining apparent in axils); very rare shrub of far north-west mallee
Leaf clusters loose, the largest leaves 2–3 mm long; widespread but not truly coastal
Leaf clusters very compact, the largest leaves to 2 mm long, or if ever to 4.5 mm long then plants coastal
Ray florets with vestigial ligules, not or barely longer than styles; probably not in Victoria, see note following genus description
Ray florets with ligules 3–6 mm long
Branchlets with dense, closely appressed tomentose hair; involucral bracts glabrous; ligules white; alps and subalps, usually near wetlands
Branchlets with loose, cottony or cobwebbed hair; involucral bracts usually with a tuft of hair or resinous glands near apices; ligules white, mauve or blue; widespread, mainly below 800 m altitude

Leaves very convex, appearing almost globular, usually less than 1 mm long, the outer ones of each cluster closely appressed to branchlets; leaf clusters usually under 1.5 mm diam., sometimes virtually contiguous and obscuring the stem
Leaves not appearing almost globular, mostly 1–2 (–4.5) mm long, not appressed to branchlets; leaf clusters mostly more than 1.5 mm diam., not contiguous
Leaves to 2 mm long; inland areas
Leaves to 4.5 mm long; coastal
Indumentum of branchlets and leaf undersurfaces closely matted, often yellowish, resinous and slightly viscid; dry rocky areas of East Gippsland
Indumentum of branchlets and leaf undersurfaces loose-cottony, white, not viscid; north and west from Port Phillip
Leaves to 8 mm long. Ray florets 7–12, white or mauve; disc florets 6–13; northwest and Bacchus Marsh areas
Leaves to c. 15 mm long. Ray florets 8–25, white; disc florets 14–50; north-central to north-west
Plants glabrous or slightly cottony, often resinous, sometimes viscid
Plants with leaves and/or stems mainly bristly or scabrous-pubescent, sometimes glandular and or with cottony hair

Leaves narrow-linear, upper surface channelled, margins usually involute; capitula in terminal, usually leafless corymbs or panicles; involucral bracts and leaves with small nodular swellings; shrubs typically of swampy ground or margins of watercourses
Leaves various, margins plane to revolute or slightly thickened; capitula solitary or in leafy panicles; involucral bracts and leaves lacking nodular swellings; shrubs typically of dry ground
Slender shrub to c. 2.5 m high, single-stemmed from base; leaves 8–55 mm long; widespread in (mostly) southern districts
Subshrub to c. 70 cm high, with several short-lived stems from a perennial rootstock; leaves 3–14 (–24) mm long; rare in south-west
Pappus no longer than body of cypsela; viscid shrub with linear leaves 8–25 mm long; apparently confined to dry rocky country along Mitchell River in East Gippsland
Pappus c. twice as long as body of cypsela; western or northern Victoria or coastal
Leaves flat (but sometimes linear); margins plane to slightly recurved
Leaves terete (or appearing so from revolute margins), or compressed-terete, virtually as thick as wide in cross-section
Inflorescence a corymb; leaves linear to narrow-obovate
Inflorescence a single terminal capitulum; leaves obovate to cuneate
Stems angled from decurrent leaf midribs; leaves obtuse, often obscurely toothed or lobed. Ray florets white; cypselas densely sericeous; twiggy shrub of drier inland areas
Stems terete; leaves acute, quite entire. Ray florets mauve, pink or white; cypselas glabrous or sparsely hairy between ribs; bushy viscid shrub of coasts
Ray florets 12–24 per capitulum, rich mauve to purple; cypselas glabrous
Ray florets 7–13 per capitulum, white to pale mauve; cypselas sericeous
Capitula 31–45 mm diam.; ray florets 18–25 mm long, pale mauve or white
Capitula 13–32 mm diam.; ray florets 4–12 mm long, white
Branchlets somewhat cottony (usually obvious in leaf-axils) but often gummed down by resinous exudate; leaves somewhat spreading, margins revolute; capitula shortly but distinctly pedunculate
Branchlets quite glabrous (but resinous); leaves subappressed to branches (rarely spreading), margins plane to slightly upcurved; capitula sessile, rarely in few-flowered corymbs

Involucre 5–6 mm long; bracts 3–4-seriate, graduating; cypselas sericeous; leaves usually excurved toward apex, convex below, sometimes narrowly grooved either side of midrib; mallee areas only (except for an isolated occurrence near Ingelwood)

Involucre 3–4 mm long; bracts 2–3-seriate, usually subequal; cypselas glabrous, blackish; leaves often slightly incurved toward apex, flat below or the midrib shallowly grooved; not in mallee areas proper
Capitula axillary or terminal, solitary or clustered, 10–25 mm diam
Capitula solitary and terminal (rarely in loose clusters) on main branches, 20–50 mm diam

Stems with dense stalked glandular hair and sessile glands; lower leaf surface lacking or with very sparse cottony hair; capitula sessile, solitary, terminal on main shoots and short lateral branches; ligules blue-mauve; montane and subalpine areas mostly above 1000 m alt.

Stems with eglandular setae, rarely with short stalked glandular overtopped by longer eglandular setae; lower leaf surface with sparse to moderate cottony hair; capitula  pedunculate from leaf axils, terminal on short lateral shoots, rarely terminal on main stems; ligules usually white, sometimes blue-mauve; coastal or inland, usually below 1000 m alt.
Younger branchlets and peduncles densely beset with short, erect, gland-tipped hairs; rare, fruitily aromatic shrub of eastern ranges
Plants non-glandular

Leaves linear, under 3 mm wide, margins revolute, coarsely ciliate especially toward base; peduncles relatively long (mostly 8–30 cm) and naked; involucral bracts graduating; scattered in heathland from mallee areas to Wilsons Promontory
Leaves obovate or elliptic, mostly wider than 3 mm, flat; peduncles under 5 cm long, or if longer then bracteate; involucral bracts subequal; mallee only
Leaves entire, narrow-obovate or -elliptic; indumentum of subappressed strigose hairs; involucre 5–7 mm long
Leaves serrate, obovate with somewhat stem-clasping bases; indumentum of coarse, spreading bristles; involucre 7–10 mm long
